It is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves that are usually arranged in a spiral pattern along the stem. The plant exhibits a creeping growth habit, often forming dense mats on the forest floor. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, typically clustered in umbels, and it is primarily found in temperate regions. Due to its specialized habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
